title: Severe myelosuppression and alopecia after thiopurine initiation in a patient with NUDT15 deficiency
summary: This article presents a clinical case of a 41-year-old South Asian female who developed severe myelosuppression, hepatotoxicity, and alopecia after initiating thiopurine therapy due to her homozygous *NUDT15* gene mutations. Thiopurines are commonly used immunosuppressants but can cause significant adverse effects, especially in patients with genetic predispositions affecting drug metabolism. Genetic testing revealed her homozygous loss-of-function alleles in the *NUDT15* gene, highlighting the importance of pharmacogenetic evaluations prior to thiopurine treatment. The case emphasizes the need for revised clinical guidelines that incorporate *NUDT15* screening, particularly given the racial disparities in mutation prevalence that affect thiopurine tolerance.

Citations: A 2014 study showed that individuals homozygous for the *3 *NUDT15* mutation tolerated only 8% of the standard mercaptopurine dose prior to significant toxicity, similar to individuals who are homozygous for *TPMT* gene mutations.

The patient underwent genetic testing and was found to have wildtype alleles in the thiopurine‐S‐methyltransferase (*TPMT*) gene, but homozygous loss‐of‐function alleles in the *NUDT15* gene (c.415C > T; *3/*3), resulting in complete loss of NUDT15 protein function.
Inherited mutations in the *NUDT15* and *TPMT* genes can increase an individual's risk of severe adverse drug reactions to thiopurine medications.
